messageBody:
The discussion is basically about two different scenarios:
1. The current sitaution
2. If the English language adopted Quikscript

In the first case, I think it makes great sense for us all to write the way we each speak. Otherwise we end up in a confusing situation, where for example, I would keep forgetting half the time that I'm supposed to write "tut-yoyo-ooze-nun" instead of "tut-ooze-nun" and "haha-ah-fife" in place of "haha-ash-fife" and countless other differences that would be totally illogical to me.

In the second case, I think we would all inevitably gravitate to national standards for our orthography (globalization notwithstanding), with personal pronunciation as an optional alternate spelling for certain uses.

This clustering of orthography by country might lead us to no longer speak of English as a single language -- just as Danish and Swedish are referred to as different languages even though they're mutually intelligible. In my own case it would be pretty easy, because any differences between my own speech and Standard American (English) are pretty minimal.

When I was just starting to learn Quickscript, it was a real challenge for me to read the sample texts at the end of the Manual, because while I was still learning to recognize and sound out the letters, I had to simultaneously "decode" a foreign dialect. At first I wondered why it's so hard to read another dialect, even though I can understand Queens Received English very easily when I hear it spoken. I think the answer is just that it's something I'm accustomed to: I've heard that dialect so much in my life that it's easy to understand; if I were a reader of Standard American QS orthography and I often read things written in QRE, then reading that dialect would become easy for me too.
